tweet: It seems like you're going for "people complain less because Apple is a higher-quality regulator than most"? That doesn't seem to be very true WRT cryptocurrency apps, but I'll grant the possibility it's more true in other areas.
Plenty of cryptocurrency apps have been blocked over the years.

That said, I think being paid $16m for creating a thing that's valued at $700m to $3b depending on how you count is fundamentally very reasonable. What's less reasonable is the bubbles that led to all of the cryptocurrencies getting so high in the first place.
Who would you call the founder of Ethereum Classic? The DAO hacker? Ok fine, I guess they have ~$50m.

See also: https://ethresear.ch/t/a-signaling-theory-model-of-cryptocurrency-issuance-and-value/1081 … TLDR: an economic model that shows how the only thing that a cryptocurrency needs to gain value is visible costly signalling, which does not necessarily need to have anything to do with underlying tech.
The $4m/year only lasts for 4 years. So that's $16m for making a $700m ($3.5b counting not yet issued coins) cryptocurrency.

It depends on the charity. If "boots on the ground" are required, you typically have to pay people or buy supplies with fiat currency and inserting cryptocurrency hence just makes things more complicated.

I think while it's an admirable cause, fiat currency is typically far more useful to the cause. It can be deployed and put to use far more quickly. It's unrealistic to expect a charity to cash out crypto to fiat.
